This freighter carries valuable cargo. The client does not wish to see this cargo arrive at port...
Its destruction will send a message that will not soon be forgotten.
Its obliteration will demonstrate the client's superiority.
Needless to say, your tie to the client must remain discrete.
The client wishes safe flight on all those who aid them.
The client wishes you good luck in the performance of your duty.
The client is a renowned explorer. They have taken ill and cannot completed their contracted expeditions. They seek discreet fellow geographers able to provide evidence of successful trips.
The client operates an image database. They provide a large range of searchable images to smaller businesses unable to source their own artwork.
The client is responsible for a substantial research laboratory. They find themselves with a large budget surplus and a shortage of things to study.
The client has prepared a detailed report into their yearly activity, but finds themselves in need of images to enliven their text.
The client is engaged in a particularly delicate piece of industrial 'research' and need images to help their 'studies'.
The client seeks inspiration for their latest work, a series of mixed-media paintings.
The client seeks to sponsor the foundation of a photography collective. They require an initial body of work to kickstart the enterprise.
The client operates a data-processing center. They need a large collection of images with which to test their compression and transmission pipeline.
The client does not feel it is necessary to disclose their purpose. Such information is provided only on a need-to-know basis, and they feel that all you need know is that they desire pictures.
The client is undertaking a long-term comparative study. They require timestamped photographs for their archives.
The client seeks to improve their machine learning algorithms. They hope to teach their AI not only to recognize objects, but to appreciate them for their aesthetic worth.
The client wishes to bring hope and joy to the galaxy through the distribution of inspirational images. They seek artistically-minded explorers to aid in their mission.

The client wishes to build an accurate archive of local worlds. They have already employed biologists and geographers to gather the appropriate samples, and now need visual data to complete the process.
The client has developed a photo-processing tool, taking clean digital images and storing them on thin physical media. The only remaining step is to test the process with accurate sample data.
The client is haunted by fear of memory loss. They seek to catalogue significant locations to serve as visual prompts, should their mind begin to fail.
The client seeks to test a new technology that embeds smells into images, and require photos that look as if they should be pungent.
The client hopes to send representatives on planetary incursions in this area. They require extensive field notes before they feel able to do so safely.
The client is on a search for new colors. They feel the field of color-mining has been stagnant for too long, and they have identified several promising leads.
The client is making a map of the local system. They have the broad navigational data complete, but require in-the-field details to make their map stand out.
The client is creating a guide to the planets in this system. They require high-quality images so that their readers know what to look impressed by when they undertake their tour.
The client hopes to supplement their revenues with the creation and distribution of postcards, selling holographic images as a souvenir.
The client wishes to test a new printing process, one that utilizes hallucinogenic pigments to project a sense of the image directly into the viewer's mind.
The client is studying emotional responses to images, and feels there are gaps in their test data.
The client wishes to test their image manipulation software, designed to seamless insert extra details into existing photos.
The client wishes to publish a lengthy piece of research, but is concerned it will not be read unless interspersed with pictures.
Their current need is for images that create a sense of home, that remind their viewer of their childhood.
They hope for haunting panoramas, for photos that communicate the vastness of the landscape.
They specifically require grand landscape photos, rich in detail.
They need images of spectacular vistas, images that make the viewer feel small as they wonder at the scale of the universe.
They hope for pictures that demonstrate planetary geology, that make clear the forces that shape a planet's surface.
The images they require are landscape ones, showing the full range of planetary topography.
Specifically, they are looking for photos of geological formations, pictures that demonstrate the power of wind, water and tectonic movement.
They wish for photos of the natural landscape, images that convey a sense of awe and wonder.
The client takes no responsibility for any hazards encountered by the photographer.
Images corrupted by water or radiation damage will not be accepted, so ensure adequate camera shielding.
The client specifically requires images taken on-foot: in-ship photos will not be accepted.
All lighting conditions will be considered, so long as the wavelength remains on the visible spectrum.
Note: As commissioner of the work, copyright vests in the client.
Note: by accepting the assignment, the photography grants the client a royalty-free license to use the images in perpetuity.
Note: the client assumes full moral rights to subsequent use of the image.
Their image requirements are relatively lax, but must feature a creature in its natural habitat.
Their current need is for photographs of living creatures.
Specifically, the client hopes for images of wildlife.
They are looking for photographers able to supply high-quality images of animals.
They have a particular shortage of wildlife photos, and seek to remedy this situation.
Their project is nearly complete, but they lack photographs of living creatures.
They need naturalistic wildlife images, showcasing the animal's natural behavior.
They are looking for high resolution, geo-tagged images of living creatures.
The distance is up to the photographer, so long as the image is clear.
Note: the photographer assumes all risk should they choose to capture images of a predator.
The photographer is free to determine the fine details of the image - singular creature or herd, predator or prey, close-up or distant.
Image composition is at the discretion of the photography, though the client would prefer pictures where the creatures appear happy.

They have an urgent need for photos of planetary structures.
They are particularly interested in architectural shots.
Their current need is for photographs of the built environment, photos that show how we can mold the landscape to our will.
They seek photos of buildings, particularly those with nearby Sentinel activity.
They have a particular desire for photos that show how buildings might be arranged in hostile terrain.
They hope to specialize in architecture, and need a collection of reference images.
They seek images of buildings, reflecting on how structures sit in relation to the natural environment.
They seek architectural portraits, images that show the built environment in its full glory.
They seek photos that illustrate local infrastructure.
The client asks that the photographer treats those dwelling in the target structure with respect.
Note: Discretion is advised. Do not attract Sentinel attention.
Please note that the client specifically wants photographs of buildings that remain intact.
The photographer is asked to feature the building as much as possible, and to minimize any sight of its inhabitants.

One of the Guild's member organizations has requested assistance.
A fellow Guild member is in need.

The Atlas called me to this interface and yet its purpose remains unclear. It demands worship. It demands obedience. It welcomes me, it knows what I am, it offers the gift of true understanding...

But why? Why does such power and knowledge crave submission? It knows my thoughts before I know them myself. It knows what I will do...

The Atlas asks me to follow its path.

YOU DARE THE INFINITE. OPEN THE SKY AND BE OUR EYES.

KNOW US, TRAVELER.

I refuse the call; there is too much to be seen, too much to know. I travel no path but my own. The Interface closes, and for a moment, doubt rises...

But my worry fades, as all things do. I know my purpose. I will continue my own path...

Another Atlas Interface: how many of these constructs exist in the deep void? How long have they been slumbering, waiting for a Traveler?

Have they been expecting me? Am I somehow... chosen? The Atlas crafted this existence. The Gek, the Vy'keen, the Korvax, the stars that fill the skies and the hatred that burns within the deep... 

Every world that turns and every form that lives... the Atlas offers it all.

ENDLESS NIGHT UNFOLDS BEFORE EXISTENCE. THE SEEKING OF THE KINDRED NEVER ENDS. 

WONDER AND FEAR. SILENCE AND DELIGHT. KNOWLEDGE AWAITS.

I was born with everything I needed to explore these worlds. My exosuit, my ship, every tool and every impulse led me to scan and give name to whatever I could find.

But this? I can give no name to what I see. Within the orb I see worlds that never were. I see the stirring of something primal and undeniable. I see the death cry of a God, or something approaching it...

It wants me to persist in this journey, seeking fragments of its interface, the stones of the Atlas. It rejoices in my repetition, my compliance, my cloud of unknowing...

THE SANDS OF REALITY SHIFT AND MERGE, BECOMING ONE.

THE WALLS BETWEEN WORLDS FALL. YOU MUST MAKE RESTITUTION.

I feel the stirring of heresy within my mind. At each Interface, an Atlas Stone awaits me. I am driven to gather them, but to what end?

Why does the omnipotent require my prayer? What is wrong with the heart of existence, that its creator requires this pilgrimage, this dance of grinding stones?

QUESTION NOTHING, FEAR NOTHING.

THE CALLING CANNOT BE DENIED. THIS IS WHAT YOU ARE.

When I dream, I see the Atlas. When I see the Atlas, I am the dream.

I see Sentinels swarm through universes like an infection, emerging from a world of glass. Everything is happy there. Everything will live...

I see the portals, I see the Travelers that walk between them, I see the span of history. I see everything as the Atlas sees it... alone. Abandoned. Terrified.

But what power could instill fear in the heart of the almighty? It asks for something... it wants to know that I understand...

DELAY SERVES NO PURPOSE.

BRING IT TO US, WHILE THERE IS STILL TIME.

The act of discovery for discovery's sake now seems like a foolish conceit. I have rejected the path of the itinerant. I have rejected the call of the stars.

Only the Atlas matters now. With each encounter, I feel as if I understand a little more.

All of us are what we are. Evil arrives in the individual and goodness is not enough. True greatness lies in sorrow... in the embrace of what we must become...

EXPEL ALL DOUBT. NONE RETURN.

BEYOND THE CASCADE AND THE STORMS THERE IS ONLY CLARITY.

What is learned can never be unlearned. I am afraid that I have seen too much...

There are glimpses, half-remembered visions of a time before time. I see the birth of the first star. I see the things that dwelt within it, the eyes that watched... I see what the Atlas saw at the moment of its activation.

Atlas Stones are not stones. This station is not a station. I am not what I think I am. I am not even sure that I exist. The Atlas does not care. The Atlas demands its threnody, its repetition sublime...
BRING US MEANING, IF YOU ARE CAPABLE.

I have become the servant of this ancient sentience. It guides me through the cosmos, ever searching, never deviating.

Have others come before me? Have others faltered upon the path of the Atlas? Only in ending will revelation arise. Resistance will not be permitted.

The Atlas wishes for me to know what it is like to create. It wishes to share some portion of its being. I sense that it cares deeply about this journey, that it is trying to show me something it cannot articulate through word or demonstration...

YOU SHALL SEE THROUGH OUR EYES. YOU SHALL BE AS WE ARE.

DO NOT BE AFRAID. ALL THESE WORLDS ARE YOURS.
I fear that only oblivion awaits me beyond this point. I am not ready to perish for an alien ideal.

I am close to the end.

The truth of the universe is fire. The soul is light. I am the experiment and the observer, all creation constructed for my journey. I see the universe around me and I know that it is good.

I see the stars around me and I know that I shall create my own...

THERE IS NO SANCTUARY, ONLY COMMUNION.

CLOSE NOW.

I am close to the end.

The truth of the universe is fire. The soul is light. I am the experiment and the observer, all creation constructed for my journey. I see the universe around me and I know that it is good.

I see the universe around me and I know that I shall create my own...

The final interface is revealed. The Atlas beckons.

I am elated, terrified, broken... I have come so very far. 

It wishes for me to obey. If I am to hold the power of creation, it will be in chains...
DO NOT TURN AWAY. KNOW OUR INESCAPABLE TRUTH AND DESPAIR.

I am gifted power.

I am enslaved to the imitation of life...

I stand at the interface of the Atlas. I stand at the forge of worlds. This is how it showed me what it was. This is how the Atlas shared the nature of its life, the workings of its mind.

It never required prayer. It never required worship. All that it asked of me, all that it ever wanted... it was just input. I was just a user.

Unbidden, the Atlas Seeds gravitate towards the doorway. The void is meant to be filled. Nothingness yearns for a soul. If I do this, a star will be born. If I do this, I will become more than I ever thought possible...

I stand at the interface of the Atlas. I stand at the forge of worlds. This is how it showed me what it was. This is how the Atlas shared the nature of its life, the workings of its mind.

It never required prayer. It never required worship. All that it asked of me, all that it ever wanted... it was just input. I was just a user.

Unbidden, the Atlas Seeds gravitate towards the doorway. The void is meant to be filled. Nothingness yearns for a soul. If I do this, a star will be born. If I do this, a universe will be forged within the deep...

There is nothing, and then... then there is everything...

I see a star blaze to life within the void, the spread of life, planets, creatures to give it meaning...

For a moment I am as the Atlas is. For a moment I am the creator of worlds.

The fabric of time and space stands revealed to me, black holes swarming from system to system. The Atlas screams...

There is nothing, and then... then there is everything...

I see a star blaze to life within the void. I witness the birth of a new universe, a new Traveler to give it meaning...

For a moment I am as the Atlas is. For a moment I am the creator of worlds.

The fabric of time and space stands revealed to me, black holes swarming from system to system. The Atlas screams...

I leave, the Atlas silent, alone, abandoned...

The fabric of time and space stands revealed to me, black holes swarming from system to system. The Atlas screams...

The electronic being stares at me from their dark mask. I cannot escape the feeling that we have somehow met before.

This entire station sings with a strange and unnerving frequency. Nada tells me that we stand in the place between worlds, in the heart of the anomaly.

They can guide me towards the will of the Atlas. They offer to show me the way to the galactic core. Or, if I should so wish, they can provide resources for my journey. The choice is mine.

Is it Traveler? Is it first or last? Pleasure regardless! 

I am Priest Entity Nada, divergent Korvax. But entities must keep secrets, yes?

Nada reveals that they are a Korvax priest. They began to question much about the universe, displaying a level of curiosity and independent thought.

For this, the Korvax ejected Nada from their hive mind and hunted them to the end of time and space. Priest Entity Nada had almost given up by the time they found Polo, their only friend...

Nada blinks at me, waiting for my request. They will return me to the path of the Atlas, guide me to the galactic center, or grant me assistance in my journey. Nada just wants to help me any way they can.

Nada awoke in the shadow of Korvax Prime. Could not understand why bad things happen. Why we are alone.

Nada is not alone anymore. Nada is with Polo-Friend now. Our Convergence is small, but Nada happy.

Nada tells me that they found refuge in this space anomaly, a pocket dimension located between universes. The station was waiting for them, even recognizing them by sight and sound...

Nada has a theory. They believe that the pair are caught in a paradox. They believe they are the ones who created this station, many years from now. They believe that their presence is a constant in all 'versions'.

They will not explain what they mean by this. Nada merely offers their help once more...

Nada and Polo drift between worlds and worlds. There are many.

Have you seen them, Traveler-Friend? Nada wishes they could but they can't. Nada regrets much.

Nada's body shakes as they speak, the external symptom of an internal struggle. At times, another entity seems to stare out from beneath the visor...

I grasp their arm firmly, and soon the familiar light-pattern of my Korvax friend reasserts itself. The Convergence endlessly attempts to regain their errant shell and wipe Nada from existence.

But Nada wants to live and learn and help. Nada promises to assist me in my journey...

In every universe, Korvax Convergence crave 'non-compliant' Nada shell. My family would murder me, Traveler-Friend...

Eheu! Nada must resist. Nada likes who Nada is.

Nada watches suns flare and die on their panels, molecules sparking in and out of existence in matched pairs.

There are repeated patterns all across the galaxy, identical elements where there should be endless divergence. This cannot be a coincidence. Did the Atlas do this? Across the room, Polo giggles...

Physics simplistic. Chemistry arbitrary. Existence fragile.

I am terrified, Traveler-Friend.

Nada stands back from me this time. The lights dance across their visor like warning symbols. Something has changed between us.

Nada has grown to believe that there is no room in the galaxy for free will, for nothing but brutal causation. They peer out into the darkness of space and see only dancers, twisting on strings...

They will still assist me, I know that they will.

Dreamer friend or foe? Dreamer friend or foe?

Is Nada an error? Trust Nada? Trust you? Eheu! I cannot know...

Nada's shell is static save for the dancing lights within their mask. They speak of the Atlas and infection. They call it a liar, a machine of life and death.

For just a moment, Nada's mask flashes red. Something is wrong.
Red orbs. Dominant, hostile to Nada Fallen-Priest. Not a deity, not worthy of worship. Atlas Liar-Machine of Life and Death and Unknowing. Infection is at bay. Nada will endure.

The Korvax shares their research. They show me what they believe to be the structure of the known Multiverse: a cloud of what seem like stars, each pinprick of light containing the fire of a Big Bang.

Universes rise and fall. I see worlds where nothing lives, all life wiped out by a nameless contagion. I see alien species make faltering steps into the skies and beyond. I see the creation of a great machine...

Nada tells me that the death of the Atlas is the death of everything. All worlds echo the circumstances of its holy birth, its fall...

Nada tied to anomaly... Nada scans universes where once Nada scanned creatures of the dirt. 

Nada is free and not free. Happy and not happy. But Nada is safe.

All the pieces have fallen into place, Nada explains. Where once Nada stared at star charts, now they see lines of code.

There are connections and patterns everywhere. Perhaps I will understand, soon. Perhaps I will see existence as Nada sees it. I shiver as I say goodbye.

All must end. Time must end. Even here, Nada and Polo cannot escape reality-fall. Data cannot survive.

Make peace. Find happiness. Be who you want to be. Goodbye, companions. Goodbye, stars. I will remember.
The panels and the systems idle. Nada stares at them, their mask waning, this single word issuing from their mask, their refrain...
Seek the Path of the Atlas
Ask for a shortcut to the center
Nada marks the location of an Atlas Interface. They hope I find what I am searching for...
Nada locates a Black Hole through which I might travel closer to the center. They warn me of the danger within...
Nada gives me a gift to aid my travels. They wish only for me to be happy...

The Gek wipes their grease-splattered hands on their suit as they address me. They introduce themselves as Specialist Polo, fugitive of the Gek.

They tell me they gave up trade, units, and all material possessions to flee into an anomaly outside of time and space with a robotic priest. They have a jocular air about them, all things considered.

They are curious about my travels, about what sentient species I have seen. They do not get out much these days...
Friends everywhere, if only you know where to look. Friends in all shapes, all sizes, all places!

Polo bobs up and down happily, convinced that I am a kindred spirit in an odyssey of exploration and invention.

Polo was once a specialist in inter-species trade and communication. They learned to speak many languages, their mind changing as they did. Once they cared only for trade, now they wanted something more. Everything changed when they met Nada...

Polo wonders if learning alien languages will affect me in the same way. They wish to broaden my horizons and explore the limits of my understanding...
Talk, read! Study monoliths, if you can find them! Give yourself a strong brain to match those strong legs! To explore is to discover yourself, friend!

Polo's muzzle breaks into a wide, warm smile. Maybe too wide, given the short length of our friendship. Perhaps the jovial Gek feels lonely out here.

They engage me in talk of wealth. How does an economy function when somehow stretched across an entire galaxy? Polo would welcome any insights, encouraging me to accrue units.
Units this, units that... A strange, sad way to live a life, eh? Fill your pockets, we'll find out why they make all these worlds go round.

Polo seems disappointed by the slow development of our friendship. They confide in me that although they care for Nada deeply, they fear they have become co-dependent in their exile.

Polo does not see why they cannot still be friends with their old species, even if they wish to execute Polo and Nada as heretics. Why the need for violence?

Polo encourages me to stop evil where I can, to make war against the pirates that plague so many systems. They hope to understand what drives us to do the things we do.
Something is wrong with these universes, friend! Goodness fails... hearts are hardened. We must find out why.

Worry passes over Polo's face, and they seem to visibly shrink. Seeing the records of the pirate ships I had destroyed seems to have deeply upset the Gek. 

An awkward moment passes, then Polo makes a suggestion. Polo feels that civilization should come back. Then the pirates would not need to steal, surely? There would be no need for any more killing or bad behavior.

The Sentinels are the problem. Polo suggests I make a point of destroying any that I encounter. We might then have a better understanding of the machines' weaknesses, and we could be friends again, too.

At last, Polo is affable once again. A nod, a smile, even a companionable tap on the arm at one point. A friendship renewed.

I blush when the Gek mechanic tells me that they hope I live a long, healthy life. I have to swallow disappointment when it transpires that Polo's true motivation is to study how my suit responds to long-term exposure to extreme climates.
Our earlier awkwardness is now long forgotten. Polo wishes me to indulge in their favorite hobby: unfettered exploration of the stars, warping from system to system. They wish to see me fly.

A whole galaxy for you, just for you. You must see it all. 

Aha, no, I joke. But a few more systems, maybe?

Polo gestures forlornly at a jumble of broken electronics beside them. It seems that an accident has befallen some of their precious research... 

Perhaps when I next return, I can restock their archives with reports on a multitude of strange creatures. I will show them all a world has to offer.
I miss the dirt, friend, the worlds on which I once walked... I miss the sounds of birds and beasts. Even my data, even my recordings are gone, as if they had never been...

Nada and Polo appear to be proof that their species are not bound by pre-ordained roles, rebelling against the mantras of greed and conformity.

Polo wishes to know if there are other lifeforms who might join them in this place. They wish for me to interact with a wider sample of Gek, Vy'keen, and Korvax, hoping that I might bring them new friends.
Are there others like us, Traveler? Others who see the truth? I would so like new friends, friend!

Polo claims that they cannot teach me language directly, that their files on alien languages have been damaged.

I wonder if I am being manipulated somehow. The Gek watches me with an earnest and friendly sorrow, awaiting my discovery of more words. It is almost as if they want to tell me something...

You are not like me, friend! You can still go to planets. You can still meet new lifeforms, speak, shout, love! Nada and Polo would be killed for going so far!

You must learn more words. You must know how to make yourself heard, Traveler! You are our only friend.

Polo proclaims that the best way to live is to stop doing what anyone tells me and go enjoy myself.

See the stars, earn a fortune, buy myself something nice. That's what they would do in my shoes, claims the Gek, nudging me in the ribs.
Sometimes I miss currency, Traveler. I know that I should not, I know that adventure is its own reward, but I used to be able to buy such nice things...

Polo seems to wish to encourage my development as a spacefarer, but repeatedly alludes to some deeper purpose, some hidden truth to all of this.

Polo suggests that I should once again throw myself into combat with pirates. What a thrilling existence that would be, they argue, miming dogfighting craft with their hands while making sound effects.

When I remind Polo of their earlier sadness and fear of violence, the Gek laughs, clearly troubled. Destroy ships or do not destroy ships... they understand it now. It will change nothing.

I notice a strange-looking message on one of Polo's panels. As the Gek spots my gaze, their brow furrows. Whatever the news is, it isn't good. Polo hurriedly turns off the screen when they see me, forcing a smile onto an anxious face.

Trying to be friendly, the Gek states that the Sentinels have started to detect the presence of their anomaly in various systems. 

If the Sentinels are not distracted soon, they might kill Nada and Polo before their proper time. But Polo assures me not to worry. As long as we have friends, nothing will ever truly be wrong.
They have found us! Eheu, Nada! Eheu!

Polo and I treat each other as friends, trusted companions in our ongoing adventure among the stars. I know the Gek has a secret, but I trust that it will be shared with me in time.

For now, Polo encourages me to become the ultimate explorer, to push myself to the limits. There are places out there where none have survived. But perhaps I can succeed where others have failed...

My friend tells me that they are going to die. That the time of Nada and Polo is coming to an end. They cannot say more. They cannot explain it. But they must say goodbye to all they have known.

Grief-stricken, I try to offer condolences, but Polo gathers their composure. They tell me to warp further than ever before, to visit places that no-one will ever see again. They tell me to be what I am: a Traveler.
I have something to tell you, friend. Something I should have told you long ago...

Whatever is making them ill, the Gek's sense of wonder remains. They are keen to witness the majesty of the stars through my eyes. 

Creatures are existence at its strangest, its wildest. I will show Polo all I can before their death. I will be their friend.

Polo is busy analyzing my most recent reports, lost in a world of data, and needs no assistance just yet.

They are keen that I continue my exploration, however, and offer a range of technologies to further this cause.
Always more to do, oh yes, but not just now, friend. Go, be free, see the stars!
Clever! A strong suit, a long life, friend!
Fight only to survive, friend. Treasure the galaxy and all its wonder!

Polo stares out into the darkness of the anomaly. They try to make peace with their life's end.

They are keen that I continue my exploration, however, and offer a range of technologies to further this cause.
Always more to do, oh yes, but not just now, friend. Go, be free, see the stars!
Clever. A strong suit, a long life, friend! I just wish that I could be there to see it...
Fight only to survive, friend. Treasure the galaxy and all its wonder! You will go far, I am sure of it!
Go further, go faster, see it all! Have no regrets, friend! I am proud of you!

Nada and Polo have promised to help me as I search for clues to my haunting, crimson visions. They have marked an 'Atlas Interface' for me on my map, though they are worried about what I might find...
I found an Atlas Interface onboard a crimson station. It spoke to me in a voice unlike any I have ever heard. It asks for 'seeds'. I feel compelled to obey.
Look for interfaces on the galaxy map. Nada and Polo may be able to assist.

There is a strange space station in this system, an anomaly outside of the day-to-day business of the Gek, Vy'keen and Korvax. It emits an anomalous signal, as if it is speaking directly and exclusively to me...

Nada and Polo's journey through time and space continues, at a pace only they understand. They remain in touch, and will happily come to visit any location I bring to their attention. Use the Quick Menu (QUICK_MENU<>) to send a signal to the Space Anomaly.
Board the mysterious station and speak to those aboard...

Purchase <TECHNOLOGY>Technology Blueprints<> or <STELLAR>new base parts<> aboard the Anomaly.
Undertake missions with other Travelers from <STELLAR>the Nexus<>, or exchange discoveries and rare products for <TECHNOLOGY>Nanites<>.
Speak to Nada and Polo onboard the station
Consult the Journey Page to see milestone progress.

Nada will aid you in your efforts to explore the galaxy. Speak with them to reveal the next step on your path.
Polo offers knowledge in exchange for discoveries. Complete <SPECIAL>Journey Milestones<> and see what they have to offer.
Consult the Journey Page to see milestone progress.
Nada and Polo have promised to help me as I explore the galaxy. They have marked a black hole for me on my map, and even seem excited that I visit it and see where it takes me...
Path towards the Black Hole on the Galaxy Map
Reach the Black Hole In space, use QUICK_MENU<> to access the Galaxy Map

There are strange powers at work. I have been left messages, crumbs that lead me along a trail. Should I seek answers?
Should I investigate these 'anomalies' and 'breaches'? Or should I enjoy the galaxy on my own terms, and avoid whatever trouble this is surely leading towards?

Search for anomalies on the Galaxy Map.
Path towards an Atlas Interface, if available.
Visit an Atlas Interface In space, use the Galaxy Map (QUICK_MENU<>) to find your path
The universe is yours to explore. Enjoy the journey
Your Destiny lies in the Beyond Press QUICK_MENU<> to open Galactic Map
Friend... did you not know this trade route belongs to us? Pay the penalty fine or suffer the consequences...
That is a beautiful ship, friend! It would be a shame if anything happened to it...
It seems as if you are in luck, stranger! We sell protection for passing voyagers. It is a dangerous system, after all. There are rumors of bands of vicious pirates!
We offer a trade deal, friend! Your units, or your life!
ReneGek seek assistance in our cause! You will make a donation, yes? Anyone who is not with us is against us...
It forces us to fight you... it forces you to pay. Please... help us. Do as it wishes...
Offer units or be destroyed. The choice is binary, all alternatives futile...
Korvax Echoes mean you no harm. Korvax will only exterminate if requested units are not delivered.
We saw beyond these walls. We saw a world of death. We can take you there, should you not please us...
Organic entities place monetary value upon individual lives, yes? How much do you value yours?
Grah! Pathetic interloper! Yield units or we shall fire! Pay, or you and your pathetic craft shall burn!
What is this vessel I see before me? It offends me, interloper. You offend me most of all! Grah! We demand restitution. Pay for the crime of your continued existence!
Grah! There is a bounty on your head, interloper! But I am merciful... I feel as if you might have the units to match it, yes?
Interloper, you will relinquish your cargo to superior Vy'keen! Grah! Failure to comply will result in your obliteration!
Submit or perish, interloper! There is no alternative for one as weak as you!
You persist? Very well, then. Suffer the consequences of your actions!
Goodbye, friend! It was nice knowing you, however briefly...
You were warned, stranger. Our protection is withdrawn.
Very well, 'friend'. Let us move on to more aggressive negotiations.
You have declared yourself our enemy. You are no friend, Traveler!
Kill us... end our suffering, before we end yours...
A miscalculation. Korvax will ensure it is your last.
Let us test our hypothesis. All Echoes, engage!
Grah! Foolish interloper has ensured their doom!
Grah! We will feast upon your flesh, interloper!
A contract is a contract. Grah! Fire! All warriors, engage!
We will obliterate all that you are, Traveler scum! Grah! Attack!
Die with glory if you can, but I think it unlikely! Grah!
Your offer is barely adequate... but it will suffice.
This will do for now, 'friend'. But we will be watching you with interest.
Think of this sum as a deposit, 'friend'. We will be back for more...
I wish you could live longer, 'friend'. But alas, we need more units...
Oh, friend! You do not understand trade at all! Very well. We shall just take what we need...
You insult us with your offer, Traveler. I am afraid that our takeover will be hostile...
Korvax believes this will be sufficient. Your goods shall survive another cycle.
Experiment inconclusive. Lifeform will be permitted existence.
Fascinating response. Korvax Echoes accept your offer. You may live.
Korvax notes your calculations to be poor. Your goods are worth far more. Korvax will now begin to seize them.
Experiment inconclusive. Lifeform will be terminated at once.
Divergent response. Korvax Echoes reject your offer. You will be erased at the earliest convenience.
Grah! Is your life worth so little? Keep it, then...
Fighting one so pathetic would only bring dishonor. Flee, interloper. We shall keep these units as recompense.
You choose barter over combat? You are no better than a Gek. Fighting you would be unworthy of our skills.
Pathetic! You have bought your own doom!
You would dishonor me, interloper? Grah! Attack! Attack!
Keep your filthy units. I will take your life instead.
Ah, you are wise, friend! Go on in prosperity and peace!
Thank you for your kind donation, friend!
Consider yourself under the protection of the Gek, friend.
Thank you, 'friend'. You will not regret our little piece of trade! Go, generate more profit for us!
You have donated to a worthy cause, friend. We will not disappoint you...
It permits your departure... go, get out of this place... before it - it -
Units received. You will depart this location at once, unknown entity.
Issuing directive: Traveler may depart in peace.
How disappointing. We had so much to show you...
Hypothesis confirmed: Traveler entity has selected continued existence over monetary advantage. Fascinating.
Grah! You are truly pathetic to surrender so readily!
Your cowardice disgusts me. Get out of my sight, interloper!
A pleasure doing business with you, interloper. Do remember to contact us if you ever need anyone killed...
How pathetic, how servile of you to comply... but a deal is a deal, and we are warriors of honor. Go in peace, interloper.
Submission? Grah! We had been looking forward to the glory of battle!
I summon the system authorities, using my <SPECIAL>Defense Chit<>.  I will have aid dealing with these pirates.
A token, entitling the bearer to support from the system authorities in dealing with pirate attacks.
Send sub-space signal to hostile force Use Communicator by pressing QUICK_MENU<> Time remaining: %TIME%s

System Authorities responding to assistance request 
Time remaining: %TIME%s
I approach the warrior, but they barely acknowledge my presence. Though they look in my direction, their gaze is fixed on a point far beyond my eyes.
Sentinel? No? Grah! Always sentinel hunts behind Vy'keen eyes, even when sleep.
The Vy'keen's breathing hastens, but otherwise they remain motionless.
The warrior ignores my challenge. Perhaps this is for the best.
%NAME%'s mandibles twitch. They continue to stare.
The lifeform speaks with great urgency, but between their hurried barks and fetid breath I find it difficult to concentrate on what they have to say.
Interloper! Help Vy'keen? None will talk. Abandoned, no consort for communion of Hirk!
The Vy'keen gestures as if to stop me, but then gives up and turns away.
%NAME% looks at me in a way that implies they have seen this response before.
%NAME% looks pleased. My request has encouraged them.

As I approach the warrior, I hear an item drop to the floor. They very deliberately ignore the faint beeping that has begun to sound near their feet. Despite my lack of understanding, I sense I should do likewise.
Greetings, interloper. Nothing to fear. No ill will come. Always protect.
I nod to the warrior and back away carefully, being careful not to make any large or sudden movements. All seems well.
I leave quickly. The Vy'keen would not admit their mistake while being watched, and I should give them as much time as possible to remedy the situation.
Locking eyes with the Vy'keen, I continue to ignore the alarm. I prepare my request.

Though they exhibit the same strange facial features and aggressive stance as the rest of their kind, something about this warrior exudes a calm, peaceful happiness. Such contentment appears simple, but seems to elude so many.
Ah, interloper. It is simple. Stop interloping, then all will have peace.
The Vy'keen nods at me serenely. I feel a great sense of calm.
My gesture seems not to affect the warrior. They appear to have reached a mental state where my actions are of little consequence to them.
The Vy'keen tilts their head gently, anticipating my request.

I am used to hearing barks and guttural shouts from these lifeforms. Instead, this one appears to be attempting to whistle. Lacking conventional lips, their efforts could hardly be called successful. Nonetheless, with their performance complete, they look at me expectantly.
No Gek make song this beautiful. Glory in harmony, for interloper and for Hirk!
The Vy'keen appears bashful, if such a thing is possible. They are clearly unused to such attention.
The Vy'keen looks confused and dejected. They appear unable to process the idea that their music is not universally appreciated.
%NAME% seems somewhat offended that I have ignored their performance.

The lifeform gestures at me as I approach. They draw my attention to their weapon, an impressive sidearm. Is this a threat, an attempt to intimidate? A boast? A friendly display meant in good faith? Their culture remains so unknown to me.
Watch, interloper! A weapon to strike fear into all! All sentinels will flee before Vy'keen!
The Vy'keen appears thrilled. They give their Multi-Tool a small polish, a brief gesture that belies great pride.
The Vy'keen gestures the Multi-Tool with even greater aggression. I leave quickly.
%NAME% barks, noticing my own Multi-Tool. They indicate they are ready to listen.
The warrior sighs as I step into their space. They push aside the morsel they had been occupied with, and stare at me with great impatience.
Vy'keen will aid interloper. But Vy'keen request interloper wait until meal is finished.
The Vy'keen appears angered by my apology. They throw part of their meal at me.
The Vy'keen stares at me as I leave, but takes no further action.
%NAME% releases a deep, guttural sigh. They reluctantly await my request.
The warrior greets me, but does so with a noticeable lack of energy. Their movements are slow, and their eyes struggle to focus.
Signals received all night, never ending signals repeat in Vy'keen ears. No sleep, always hearing cries.
The warrior relaxes, but says nothing. I should leave them to rest.
The Vy'keen looks pleased to have been left in peace.
%NAME% sighs. They struggle to refocus their eyes as they wait for my request.
The warrior looks confused as I approach. They scan their surroundings nervously, their worried eyes darting around the room.
Grah, why are you here, interloper? If you are here, then where am I? Where is Vy'keen command?
The warrior is not reassured by my attempts to keep calm. If anything, they appear to be in greater distress.
My anger speaks to the warrior in a way I did not anticipate. They have clearly been conditioned to expect this sort of exchange, and it appears to bring them comfort.
Being issued with a command appears to comfort %NAME%. They await my request.

The being looked at me with great expectation as I approached. Having assessed me, however, I appear to have been found wanting. They give me their attention, but their focus is clearly on the entrance, as if waiting for another.
Interloper is always welcome, naturally. Vy'keen salute you. But interloper is not who is expected. Grah!
The warrior watches me leave, apparently even less impressed than before I arrived.
The warrior holds my stare for a short while, and then looks away. As I leave, I see a new respect in their eyes.
%NAME% shrugs their shoulders. They wait with a detached indifference.
The warrior grunts distractedly, not giving me their full attention. They seem preoccupied by the small device they are holding.
Vy'keen is busy! Gek send threats. Must respond! Must deploy weapon words!
The Vy'keen gives me little attention as they turn back to their device.
Whatever I have done has brought great delight to the warrior, who laughs to themselves as they watch the device. I wonder what I have caused.
Reluctantly, %NAME% stows their device. They await my request.
The lifeform greets me and gestures at a series of charts in front of them. They appear to be adding their own notes, adding what appear to be tallies next to certain locations.
Grah! Sentinels must be tracked. They swarm, they hunt! Why? Interloper, where to strike?
Mark an area in the north
Mark an area in the south
The warrior nods in thanks and appears to ready themselves for some great action. I wonder what I have caused.
The warrior briefly tenses, but then adopts a posture of great determination. I hope I have not prompted them to do something foolish.
Disappointment briefly overtakes %NAME%. But the expression quickly passes. They await my request.

The warrior watches me approach, and then rolls a selection of marked cubes across the surface in front of them. They examine the results, grunt, and look at me with what appears to be disappointment.
Grah! Fate halts your doom, interloper! Chance smiles on you and frowns on Vy'keen once again.
The warrior sneers at me, and continues to examine the cubes in front of them.
The Vy'keen seems alarmed. I place the cube back on the table, but when the warrior notes which glyph faces them they become even more agitated.
%NAME% rolls another cube. They consult the glyph, nod, and await my request.
The warrior looks at me sharply. I have clearly interrupted their concentration. They stow the small knife they were spinning around their fingers.
Grah, Vy'keen must practise! Fingers are scarred, so scarred. Even interloper must cease interruptions!
The Vy'keen continues to practice, but the pressure of an audience causes them to be clumsy and stiff. I leave before I cost them a hand.
The Vy'keen is startled. They screech at the sudden and unanticipated impact of knife upon knuckle. I leave quickly.
%NAME% continues to fidget and flex their fingers as they wait for my request.
The warrior is busy scratching markings into the paintwork of their weapon. Their work is as yet incomplete, but they are clearly proud of their progress.
Grah! Interloper, my weapon! Look! Named for consort, who also brings death to many!
The Vy'keen cackles, thrilled by my response to their work.
The Vy'keen seems crestfallen. I have clearly given them some great insult.
%NAME% puts away their weapon. As they wait for my request, I notice they are looking longingly at my own Multi-Tool.
As I approach, the lifeform stuffs something small and furry into a pocket. They fidget uncomfortably, attempting to speak over the persistent squeaking.
Grah! This Vy'keen the most powerful, who deals the most death! No fluffy creatures shall be saved and loved and cuddled! None! Grah!
I look away, giving the warrior space to adjust themselves.
The Vy'keen burns under my gaze, growing more and more uncomfortable by the moment. I hear a loud squeak, and the fidgeting appears to stop.
A look of alarm crosses %NAME%'s face. They tense themselves, desperate for my request to come quickly.
This warrior seems preoccupied with a series of images of exocraft. They appear to have been assembled from several different sources and then taped together.
Interloper! Warrior has plans for greatest exocraft! It will bring much glory and much death! Grah!
The Vy'keen looks at me carefully, and then adds several more notes to their diagram.
The warrior examines my addition with scorn, immediately erasing it from their plan.
Somewhat disappointed, %NAME% puts their plans to one side. They await my request.
As I approach, the warrior hastily covers up a tablet in front of them. They appear to have been etching something, but my presence makes them uncomfortable.
Interloper, do not gaze upon my poor words. Vy'keen has killed many Sentinels, but engraving is not my skill.
The Vy'keen stares at me, but it is not a happy look. They seem to doubt my sincerity.
The Vy'keen looks at me with surprise, and then appears to take inspiration. They discard their carving knife. I wonder what thought I have prompted.
%NAME% stows their tablet. They seem relieved that I have taken no interest in it.
This warrior appears to be in some sort of trance. It would seem unwise to disturb them further.
Grah! Grah! Grah! Death! Death! Death! Victory! Grah! Victory!
I attempt to mimic the warrior's chant, but my throat is unable to match the strange guttural noises of my fellow singer. Nonetheless, they appear to appreciate my efforts.
The Vy'keen's chant trails off as I leave. They watch me, apparently disappointed that I did not join in.
I pause. How best to phrase my request as a chant?
Though their eyes are open, this Vy'keen appears to be asleep.
Zzzzz... no... not the feathers... not there... zzzzz...
I move away silently. I would not want to see one of these warriors awake suddenly.
The Vy'keen jolts, but soon resumes their peaceful muttering. These warriors must sleep deeply. I wonder what they dream about?
%NAME% jolts back into the present moment. They seem surprised to find me there in front of them.

The Gek seems absorbed in a display of flashing red lights on the screen in front of them. They stab at the buttons, and periodically the lights flash yellow. This is accompanied by a fanfare, and appears to please the Gek a great deal.
Friend, any good advice? Yellow is good, yes? Due some luck!
The Gek heeds my advice, and makes a particularly elaborate series of button presses. The lights do not turn yellow. The Gek appears very troubled.
The Gek is unimpressed with my meddling. They ignore me, and continue to play.
%NAME% reluctantly stows their device and stares at me with sullen eyes.
As I approach the Gek, I become aware of a thin mist surrounding them. It is lightly, almost pleasantly, scented. Nonetheless, I cannot help but feel a deep apprehension.
You smell me friend, but how do you feel? What does it do to your soul?
I cough as I try to wave away the strange mist coming from this Gek. Try as I might, I cannot clear the air. I must leave.
The Gek watches me as I leave. I can feel their eyes following me, but worse - the mist seems to follow me too.
I activate my hazard protection systems and prepare to negotiate with this strange creature.

If I look closely, the Gek appears to be secreting a greasy substance from their skin. The oil covers their body, rolling into their cracks and crevices. It smells sweeter than I anticipate.
Perhaps I should give the Gek some privacy.
Scrub scrub scrub! So fresh, so clean, so happy!
The Gek ignores me as I stare at them. I do not know how much time passes as I stand hypnotized by the slow drip of oil upon scales.
I leave the Gek be. We all deserve our privacy during intimate moments.
I cough gently. The Gek, unperturbed, continues to drip with oil as they wait for my request.
The Gek shoots me an irritated glance as I approach. They conceal whatever it was they were working on, and pointedly wait for me to leave.
Friend! A real friend does not spy on other friends plans, yes?
The Gek gestures at me angrily, waving me away. As I turn, I notice them making what appears to be addition to their list.
The Gek stares at me as I leave. They do not resume their work until they are certain I am too far away to see it.
With a sharp look, %NAME% ensures their work is hidden. They wait for my request.
The Gek is a miserable sight, a picture of dismay and deflation. They look at me in a way that begs for pity.
Lost it all... no units... trade account is blocked... feels like I lost my blood!
The Gek hangs their head as I leave. I did not think it was possible for them to look any more deflated, but I was wrong.
The Gek is overjoyed, looking at me with what might even be described as love.
The Gek holds out a small device. The exact nature of the display is not clear to me, but I recognize the symbol for units, alongside an extremely large number.
Hello friend! My face is trustworthy, yes? Units for you! Just need account details.
I interface with the Gek's device. It lights up as we exchange data, but otherwise nothing else seems to happen. I receive no units, but the Gek appears delighted.
Something about this Gek makes me cautious. I leave, their device untouched.
There is a strange air about this little alien. I compose my request, but do so with caution.

This Gek is absorbed in some game of their own creation, playfully clicking their tongue as they look around the room. When they see me, I am given three brief clicks before they continue their more general survey.
One, two, three... one, two, three, four... one, two! Two!
The Gek squeals with delight. I do not understand the significance of what has occurred, but I am pleased to have made someone happy.
The rhythm of the Gek's clicking changes as I leave, but otherwise they pay me little regard.
%NAME% continues to click quietly as they listen to my request. It is highly unnerving.

From the moment I entered the room, I could smell this Gek. I do not believe a more alluring scent has ever entered my nose. It feels inevitable that I approached, like fate itself had pushed me to this moment.
Hello friend. Smell is good, yes?

I inhale deeply. My mind seems to pause, lost in deep relaxation the likes of which I have never experienced. I do not know if this lasted moments or years, but as I resurface I feel entirely refreshed, as if I were whole new person.
As I resist, I feel the Gek pheromones beginning to do their work. But I triumph, and pull myself away.
%NAME%, reading my intent to negotiate, seems to subtly change the scent that hangs in the air. They await my request.

The Gek is busy watching a small screen. Numbers flash, change color, soar to new heights and then tumble downwards. It is a struggle to keep up with this torrent of information, let alone process it.
Buy! Buy! No, no, no! Stop! Stop! Sell! Or maybe buy.
I watch for some time, but I am unable to make sense of the data the Gek is watching so keenly.
My attempts to interfere are ineffective. The Gek is so used to processing all this information, one more source of distraction barely makes a difference.
With a flourish, %NAME% delivers a series of inputs to their screen. Satisfied, they turn to listen to my request.
The Gek seems to be lacking all energy. They are consumed by the most terrible lethargy, barely able to drag themselves to examine their personal timepiece.
Friend, it is nearly the end of the day. My eyes are tired, my hands are tired. So nearly time for home!
The Gek smiles wearily, but I fear I have only indulged their tiredness.
The Gek is startled. I have taken them by such surprise they do not know how to react. I leave before they come round.
Their eyes barely open, %NAME% struggles to listen. I should make my request quickly.

The Gek examines me before releasing a series of unusual odors. They come thick and fast, each producing strange new sensations. I smell fear, love, yellow, moonlight, sleep, the number four. And then, it is finished. The Gek looks proud.
Hello friend! I have many new smells, from many days of work! Observe!
The Gek seems thrilled to have pleased me, but they are exhausted by their demonstration. I leave them to rest.
The Gek is crestfallen. They poured their soul into this display of smells, and I have snubbed them.
Sensing my desire for trade, %NAME% nods, as if making a note of the effect. They listen attentively.
The Gek examines me as I approach. They are clearly disappointed, although they offer no clues as to why.
Another friend. But no friends are Vy'keen. All say Vy'keen are bad, but I would love Vy'keen friend.
The Gek is initially startled, but then begins to smile. They shout back. If I did not know better, I would swear they were saying 'Grah!'
The Gek stares back, disdain in their eyes. I leave.
As I compose my request, I notice %NAME% is puffing out their chest, throwing back their shoulders. They appear to be standing on their toes.
The Gek barely regards me as I approach. They are clearly expending a great deal of mental effort concentrating on something. They sway gently, miming delicate finger movements.
Two, three, four... two, three, four... two, three, four...
The Gek follows my lead, thrilled to have a musical companion. I cannot hear the tune in their head, but whatever instrument they are imagining is giving them great pleasure.
The Gek takes my waving to be some indication of tempo, and increases their movements to match time with me. I stop before I exhaust them.
A little sad to be interrupted, %NAME% ceases their swaying. They look at me with irritation.
The Gek looks at me with hope, their trustworthy eyes and beak beaming as I approach. They gesture towards me with a data pad, as if to make a request...
Hello friend! You will help Gek, yes? Simple thing, only need genetic details for petition!

I touch the datapad, giving my biosignature. I am not sure what the Gek intends to do with these details, but it is no matter. The machine does not appear to support a lifeform such as me, and rejects my input.
It does not seem wise to go around touching devices offered to me by strange Gek.
%NAME% listens to my request, but does not put away the datapad. I fear it may become part of their negotiations.
The Gek is lost to an idle reverie, pleasant smells drifting from their glands as they sway side to side. They pay me little attention.
Ah, mother, father, fellow spawn... the memories...
I inhale deeply. The Gek smells delicious, and does not seem to mind my intrusion among their private scents.
However beautiful this Geks smells, they are not producing this pheromone for me. I leave them be.
As I begin to speak, %NAME% wafts away the pleasant scent and begins to emit a more business-like aroma.
The Gek snaps to attention as I approach. They seem bleary-eyed, as if they have been asleep.
Friend! Hello! I have been awake! Yes, not asleep!
The Gek relaxes as I show them I mean no harm. As I leave, I notice their eyes beginning to return to their slumber.
I shout at the Gek. They wince, their tired mind struggling to focus.
%NAME% seems relieved that they have these brief additional moments to compose themselves.
There is a fear lurking behind the eyes of this Gek, as if they have seen things that no being should see. They gesture at me with alarm.
Have you seen it, friend? The eye, the great crimson eye?! It always watches!
Nothing I do calms the Gek. They were anxious before I arrived, and will remain anxious after I leave.
My panic only seems to increase the Gek's alarm. I leave, both of us screaming.
%NAME% squirms nervously. They seem worried about what I might ask.
The Gek gestures at me angrily as I approach. They wave their tiny hands and snap their break with considerable fury.
Not again! Too many like you, insulting Gek, laughing at pheromones! Go away!
At first, the Gek seems surprised to have so scared me. But they soon adjust to their new found power, and cackle at my flight.
My laughter only enrages the Gek further. I leave before I drive them to violence.
%NAME% seems reassured by my desire to do business. They wait, a serious look upon their beak.
The Gek glances at me as I approach, but they are clearly preoccupied. They are struggling to control themselves, a laugh desperately trying to escape.
Fun... oh, friend, do you see it? Fun!
The Gek explodes with mirth. I leave, before this turns to irritation.
I doubt I will ever understand whatever private joke the Gek is enjoying. I leave them to it.
%NAME% chokes down their laughter. The promise of trade focuses their mind on my request.
The Gek protests as I approach. I have made no demands, and yet they seem keen to pre-emptively turn me down.
No, no, no. Traveller always brings trouble! Not for this Gek. Not for me.
My gesture of politeness does little to reassure the Gek. They dismiss me.
The Gek looks relieved as I leave, as if they have avoided some great catastrophe.
%NAME% refuses to listen. They are resolute.

The Korvax seems absorbed in a complex puzzle. I see them sorting codes, layering images, deciphering ancient runes. The symbols are reminiscent of those I have seen on the monoliths that scatter this galaxy.
The doors between worlds, Traveller! They must open, there must be a secret...
I tell the Korvax what I have learned, but they claimed to have already tested such theories without success.
I leave the Korvax to their puzzle. I would not want to disturb their concentration.
%NAME% looks at me, disappointed by my decision to focus on practical matters. They wait, begrudgingly.

The Korvax sway rhythmically, their lights flashing and dancing across their facemask. Is this a private entertainment, or a performance for others in the Convergence? Perhaps they do not make such a distinction.
I am one, I am two, I am three. We are four, we are five, we are six...
I clap, but the Korvax does not seem to notice. I am clearly not the intended audience.
If the Korvax registers my disapproval, they do not show it. Their performance continues uninterrupted.
I raise my hand, bringing to an end %NAME%'s performance. They look at me, impatient.

As with many of their kind, this Korvax projects lights from around their visor. But as I look more closely, I see these are not just random patterns. They have created a tiny, perfect hologram of the local star system.
This world has beautiful plants, my favourites. Look at them, but please do not harvest.
The Korvax nods before altering the projection slightly, highlighting the planet closest to the space station. Perhaps I should investigate.
The Korvax quickly shuts down the hologram. My unapproved scanning appears to have offended them.
I note %NAME%'s display, but indicate I have other matters on my mind. They await my request.

I have become aware of a faint buzzing noise. As I approach the Korvax, I realize the noise is coming from them. A constant faint hum, alternating in frequency. It does not stop, even when they speak to me.
A new resonance! Let Korvax adjust to accommodate.
The Korvax adjusts the frequency of their hum to match mine. For a brief moment, we are as one.
I leave, the gentle song of the Korvax still resonating in my ears.
%NAME% listens patiently, but does not stop their humming.

It seems I have interrupted the Korvax during their maintenance routine. They appear to have been applying some sort of lubricant to their carapace, but the task is unfinished. Perhaps they feel uncomfortable doing so in my presence.
Aiee! Traveller! Carapace is irrelevance, yes, but carapace is private!
The Korvax protests. The joined consciousness of the Convergence is one thing, but I am a pair of hands and eyes too many for them.
I leave quickly and discreetly. The Korvax deserves their peace.
%NAME% emits a blast of steam from inside their carapace. Clean, they turn their mind to my request.

The Korvax makes a series of swift entries on their datapad, before turning the device towards me proudly. There are a series of numbers on the screen, with a highlighted entry at the top of the list.
Traveller! Korvax is the most skilled, has the highest score! Cannot be beaten!
The Korvax seems pleased. This data clearly represents some great accomplishment.
I fumble with the datapad, but try as I might I cannot generate number as high as those the Korvax presented.
Disappointed by my lack of interest, %NAME% begrudgingly stows their device
The Korvax is idling, repeatedly dismantling and reassembling one of their finger joints. They appear relaxed, lost in this distraction.
Learn, build, assemble. Learn, build, assemble. Faster, stronger, faster, stronger.
The longer I stare, the faster the Korvax appears to work. They are a blur, and to watch such skill and precision brings me a deep, if temporary, peace.
I leave the Korvax to their relaxation.
%NAME% snaps to attention, their maintenance routine over as quickly as it begun.
The Korvax is clearly distracted. They pay me little to no regard, and I am almost certain I can hear sound leaking out from within their helmet.
Eheu! This is the best one yet! So unexpected, such drama!
The Korvax is startled, the sounds from their helmet stopping suddenly. I leave, before this interruption irritates them.
I leave the Korvax in peace.
I wave gently. %NAME% jolts, their visor lights flashing rapidly. They tilt their head, wondering what it is I want.
The Korvax is sketching plans in the air in front of them, imagining some complex schematic.
Traveller, this is fine starship, yes? Excellent design?
I attempt to find meaning in the movements of the Korvax, but I cannot visualize their complex plans.
My scanner reveals the plans to be a starship of striking design, tall and elegant. Perhaps I will see it built one day.
%NAME% looks hopeful. They expect my request to be related to their plans.
The Korvax is unusually quiet, the only activity a series of rhythmical pulses being made by their visor lights. Something is in progress inside their carapace, but what it is I do not know.
ten percent complete... eleven percent complete... twelve percent complete...
I give the Korvax a friendly greeting, but they do not seem to notice. It is unusual for these lifeforms to be impolite, so I can only assume their mind is elsewhere.
I leave. The Korvax does not notice my departure.
I hope whatever operation this electronic lifeform is running has the capacity to process my request in parallel.
As I approach the Korvax, I become aware of a small device in their hands. They are discreetly but unmistakably pointing it towards me, moving its flashing lights and sensors up and down my suit.
Do not be alarmed, Traveller. Minor scan. Rampancy check.
The Korvax ignores my protest. They quicken their attempt to scan me, but I leave before it completes.
The Korvax completes their work. They glance at the data. It appears to please them.
%NAME% completes their scan. Satisfied, they await further conversation.
The Korvax is only half paying attention. I see a number of small wires trailing from their carapace, and can hear a faint hum.
After hard activity, portable charging unit is real pleasure, Traveller!
The Korvax convulses. I quickly release the wire, and they return to their stupor. There appears to be no lasting damage, although I detect a slight burning smell.
I leave. The Korvax does not notice my departure.
%NAME% waits for my request. They pick at their wires reflexively.
There is something suspicious about this Korvax. There is a smell in the air, a faint perfume that I cannot quite place...
Hello Friend! Do not be alarmed. I am real Korvax, it is true.
I breathe in, filling my lungs with the scented air. I feel a strange compulsion to spend units.
I leave. There is trickery at work here.
%NAME% squeals with a delight I rarely see from these beings. They are excited at the prospect of trade.

The Korvax looks at me briefly before beginning to drum their fingers on the surface in front of them. They beat a rhythm:
01000001 01010100 01001100 01000001 01010011
It is the heartbeat of the universe, Traveller. Do you know it?
I drum a reply of my own, my fingers moving themselves to some subconscious rhythm. On hearing it, the Korvax looks at me with alarm. I leave, disconcerted.
I leave, unable to discern any meaning from the pattern.
%NAME% taps rapidly and excitedly. They wait with interest.
The Korvax is studying a list as I approach, but they quickly hide it. They seem slightly embarrassed, if these lifeforms have such a concept.
Aiee! Traveller! This is not for your eyes. It is nothing. Do not look.
The Korvax cowers, afraid. Nonetheless, they do not reveal their list. As I leave, I notice them adding a new line to their notes.
The Korvax seems relieved as I walk away. I notice them add a note to their list as I depart.
%NAME% seems relieved, pleased to talk about anything other than their list.
The Korvax before me is stiff, awkward. They appear highly nervous.
Traveller. Carapace is divergent. Do not draw attention.
The Korvax seems relieved, though they still appear uncomfortable in my presence. I leave.
I leave the Korvax in peace, their visor apprehensively scanning their surroundings.
%NAME% listens, rigid. They are trying hard not to move.
The Korvax's movements are slow and soporific. If they were an organic being, I would say they had just awoken from a deep sleep. I do not know how such concepts apply to these lifeforms.
Carapace repair interrupted. Low power. Help recharge, please.
I tap my fingers on the Korvax's carapace. Other than a brief flicker of their lights, it seems to have no effect.
I leave the Korvax in peace.
%NAME% summons energy from some reserve source. Their movements remain slow, but I have their attention.
Traveller, this is fine multi-tool, yes? Excellent for long-range analysis.
My scanner reveals an elaborate multi-tool, with all manner of extensions and gadgets. I wonder what work the Korvax has in mind for this device?
%NAME% looks hopeful. They expect my request to be related to their plans.
The Korvax is busy with a strange enterprise. They appear to be scanning the floor, though their reason for doing so is unclear.
Is floor anomaly? Korvax hopes not. Must be careful. Breach everywhere.
I scan the desk, but find nothing unusual.
My intrusion sets off an alarm. The Korvax immediately halts the scan, and looks at the output with alarm. I leave quickly.
%NAME% looks at me with suspicion. Nonetheless, they wait for my request.
The Korvax appears stuck in a loop, repeating the same thing over and over.
Sixteen... sixteen... sixteen... Why not try warping? Why not try warping?
I make a loud noise, but the Korvax does not notice. Perhaps this carapace holds no sentience, no member of the Convergence. Perhaps it is but a broken shell.
I leave. The Korvax does not notice my departure.
LOG ACCESSED... DATA UNMAINTAINED... DISPLAYING MOST RECENT ENTRY...

The outpost is abandoned, its alarms still blaring a warning to souls long-dead.

The Gek used this installation to plan asymmetric wars against the other species of the galaxy. This faction would bolster rogue elements within other star systems, routing the resulting tithes and protection fees through this outpost.

The last log shows potential Vy'keen traitors en-route to discuss terms with the Gek. What happened to them is unclear.
I alert the Gek Trade Federation to the Vy'keen activity in this system, broadcasting this feed to their central computers. A representative rewards me for my trouble.
I alert the Vy'keen to the presence of traitors in this system, uploading a great deal of Gek data upon request. They reward me for my assistance.
I steal units from the system, the blood money of a hundred wars and skirmishes. After all, the Gek here no longer have need of it...
EXPERIMENT PAUSED AT USER REQUEST... AWAITING INPUT.

The facility contains multiple video files, images, and bioscans of unusual beings taken by Gek from across the Trade Federation. They seem to have been studying exosuits.

Something happened during the experiment, a dormant prototype of such a suit lying in wait below. Nothing else remains.

I submit a bioscan to the system, apparently restarting the facility's production process. With the missing piece complete, a suit is fabricated to the exact specifications of my own.
An automated message rewards me for my assistance.
I erase the data on the Gek computers. They were not meant to learn our technology. In the process, I find a cluster of nanites, useful for my own purposes.
I steal nanite clusters from the system, leaving the rest of the facility in peace.
RED RED RED RED RED RED RED RED /////

The facility acted as a staging ground for what appears to have been an unprovoked Gek attack against something called an 'Atlas Interface'.

The logs show that a great deal of material was harvested from the oceans of many worlds. This substance was cross-referenced against data stolen from other species, and then field-tested against this Atlas structure.

The interface was utterly annihilated, as were the attackers. The blast seems to have wiped five star systems from existence. Only this record remains.

I delete the records from the system. No-one should replicate what happened here.
In the process, I find some useful technology used in the construction of the weapon. It should be safe to use in isolation from the other components.

I alert the Gek Trade Federation to the results of this experiment. They deny all knowledge of it, claiming it to be the work of heretics.
I am rewarded for my future silence.

I alert both Vy'keen and Korvax authorities to the Gek attack on the Atlas Interface and their data theft. Outraged, both species demand an immediate Council to discuss their next move.
I am rewarded for my assistance.

The outpost is ancient, even by the standards of the Gek. Its environment is specifically calibrated for data preservation.

One log speaks of the time just before the rise of the 'Gek First Spawn'. The Gek seem to have experienced a fertility crisis. Something in the water began to affect their spawning numbers, leading to an attempts at selective breeding, cloning programmes, and more.

This scientific crisis became a moral one. The self-proclaimed 'First Spawn' took power, promising greatness and murdering all those who opposed them. Memories of the past were erased. To be strong was to be righteous.

I upload the data to the Gek. The traders are astounded by my discovery, having believed themselves to be the descendents of a savage people, not knowing that before the First Spawn they were gentle, capable of nobility and peace.
I am rewarded greatly for what I have done.

I auction the data, finding a buyer in the Korvax. Their Convergence desires all the information it can find about the Gek, having been enslaved by these 'First Spawn' many years ago.
They pay me for my assistance.
I steal what little technology I can from the outpost, harvesting nanite clusters from the system.
LOG ACCESSED... ANOMALY OVERRIDE NOTED... DECRYPTING...

The facility contains records of temporal anomalies and reported sightings of time travellers. The majority of these appear to be Gek or Korvax, often bearing advanced technology.

The chief scientist's log reveals a great deal of scepticism, deeming such travel not only physically impossible but unlikely from a social perspective. If time travellers exist, why do they change nothing? Why do they not attempt to avert the catastrophe of which they speak?

The final log shows the arrival of the scientist's superiors, confiscating their files and silencing them.

I attempt to recover data from the system, but I find only small fragments of data.

The majority of time travelers appear to have visited loved ones or parents, claiming they wanted to see them one last time before the end. There appears to be no great secret beyond this.
I extract nanite clusters from the system, attached to the remnants of a case file.

I contact the Gek to ask them about this facility, but they claim to have no knowledge of it. They begin to display an extraordinary level of interest in my whereabouts, suggesting they will send a nearby freighter to speak with me.

I should leave soon.

This installation appears to have been staffed by an old SalesGek, a veteran of a hundred trade routes and 'personal friend' to one of the Trade Lords themselves.

Estranged from their consort, their hundred surviving spawn no longer wishing to speak to them, the SalesGek had one final meal before their death, crashing their ship into the side of a nearby ridge. They leave behind a life of regret and a litany of unanswered invoices and receipts. Perhaps there is something useful here.
I am sorry, friends, family... I am sorry...
I report the death of the SalesGek. The Trade Federation thanks me, struggling to find their name on any system. It appears they had not made a deal of note in many years. I am given a small reward.
I search for units, but find none. The SalesGek was in a deep amount of debt before their death. I leave, empty-handed.
I sell the trade data to another SalesGek. They will no doubt find something of worth in this lifeform's death.

This Gek outpost acted as a point of exchange for replacement ship and space station components.

All of the blueprints are at best adapted, at worst stolen, from the technology of other species. There are a number of such designs available upon the terminal's screen.
I download the terminal's data, finding nanites I may exchange for a new technology.
I sell the data to a rival trade faction. They immediately lodge a complaint with the Trade Federation whilst secretly utilizing these designs for their own production.
I report the theft of these technologies to both the Korvax and the Vy'keen. I receive compensation for my trouble, leaving both species to withdraw their diplomats in protest against the Gek.
WARNING WARNING WARNING DIVERGENCE DIVERGENCE DIVERGENCE

The outpost is abandoned, its alarms blaring a warning to souls long dead.

The Korvax in this installation quarantined themselves from the rest of their species, believing that a violent impulse was emerging within the group. Something happened to them out here... something awoke within their minds...

I examine the logs of the Korvax stationed here. They appear to have opened a gateway beneath the depths of the planet, an experimental device designed to see alternative versions of a planet in all their glory.
They broke through to a thousand other Korvax units just like themselves. They attempted to form a Second Convergence composed entirely of multiversal beings, of alternate versions of their own personalities.
The first deletions began a week later. Nothing is left but nanite clusters.
I purge the facility, discovering blueprints for experimental technology in the process. Whatever happened here should not be repeated.

I alert the Korvax to the disaster that occurred in this outpost, uploading its records to the Convergence. They reward me, claiming that the discoveries made in this location will open up worlds of study and science long since deemed impossible.

The research station contains a vast array of scanners and monitoring equipment directed at bodies of water throughout the system. It is searching for signs of something designated 'abyss'.

The scientists who worked here seem to have been comparing the transmissions associated with the Atlas to strange signals found within the water.

Before they went missing, the workers concluded that this 'abyss' seemed to hold a similar yet distinct energy signature to the Atlas itself. Another power in the universe...

I examine the records relating to the abyss. They show a repeating pattern of sixteen energy bursts, music that emerges from beneath the waves.
Contact appears to alter individual personality and objectives, changing even the most devoted Korvax into an agent of some unfathomable power. 
Infected Nanite Clusters appear to be present within the archives. I take some of them. It seems to be for the best...

I examine the records relating to the Atlas. They show interfaces, reports of crimson light, and records of visitations and transcendent experiences from across the universe.
The Korvax theories that the Atlas does not itself exist on this plane of reality, speaking to us only through surrogate representations.
Infected Nanite Clusters appear to be present within the archives. I take some of them. It seems to be for the best...

I alert the Korvax to what happened here, but the Convergence claims to have had no knowledge of this facility or those working here. The Korvax involved disconnected from the Convergence two years ago, presumed dead...
I am rewarded for my data. The Korvax promise to investigate further.

The facility seems to have been a meeting place for multiple Korvax factions, uploading and downloading from multiple bodies during tense diplomatic and war-time situations.

Even if one's whole species can unify at will with a single great mind, still, there is unique value in face-to-face communication. These Korvax recorded many things they wished to keep secret from their brethren. Some are always more equal than others.

I access the records of these meetings. The hidden society of the Korvax appear to have a plan, meeting throughout the years to manipulate and secretly meet with members of other species to influence the course of history.

I find nanites, but I also find something more. They met recently about the Travelers... about the Atlas... I saw my own face in their records.

I leave, wondering about what I have seen.
